choices.text: Obtaining a biopsy sample from the most tender area of the artery
Using a large bore needle for biopsy
Obtaining a biopsy segment of at least 3-5 cm in length
Performing the biopsy under general anesthesia

questions.text: During a temporal artery biopsy for suspected giant cell arteritis, which of the following factors is MOST important for improving diagnostic yield?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obtaining a biopsy segment of at least 3-5 cm in length

 

Option C:

 

Due to the segmental (patchy) nature of vascular inflammation in giant cell arteritis, obtaining a longer segment (3-5 cm) of the temporal artery is crucial to increase the chances of finding the diagnostic histopathological changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Obtaining a biopsy sample from the most tender area of the artery: While tenderness might indicate inflammation, a longer segment is more important for sampling.

 

Option B. Using a large bore needle for biopsy: The needle size is less relevant than the length of the biopsy specimen.

 

Option D. Performing the biopsy under general anesthesia: General anesthesia is not typically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adequate biopsy length is essential for accurate diagnosis of GCA. While other factors like tenderness or imaging findings can guide the biopsy site, the length of the specimen is the most critical determinant of diagnostic yield.

choices.text: Discontinue prednisone and observe for symptom resolution
Order a temporal artery ultrasound
Perform a temporal artery biopsy
Increase the dose of prednisone

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of headaches, jaw claudication, and scalp tenderness. She has been taking low-dose prednisone for polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform a temporal artery biopsy

 

Option C:

 

While glucocorticoids can improve symptoms, they may not completely suppress vascular inflammation. Biopsy should be performed promptly, even if the patient is already on glucocorticoids, as histologic findings may still be present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Discontinue prednisone and observe for symptom resolution: While low-dose prednisone may be used to manage polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), it's not sufficient to treat giant cell arteritis (GCA). Discontinuing it without a definitive diagnosis could lead to worsening symptoms and potentially irreversible vision loss.

 

Option B. Order a temporal artery ultrasound: While ultrasound can be a helpful tool in the assessment of GCA, it is not as definitive as a biopsy. A negative ultrasound doesn't rule out GCA, and a positive result still requires biopsy confirmation.

 

Option D. Increase the dose of prednisone: Increasing the dose of prednisone without a biopsy-confirmed diagnosis of GCA is not recommended. Higher doses of prednisone carry a significant risk of side effects, and it's important to establish the diagnosis first to determine the appropriate treatment course.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and treatment of GCA are crucial to prevent complications like vision loss. Even if a patient is already on glucocorticoids, a biopsy should not be delayed, as it is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis.

choices.text: Continue with oral prednisone 40 mg daily
Increase the dose of oral prednisone to 60 mg daily
Administer intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days
Refer urgently to ophthalmology for assessment

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with newly diagnosed temporal arteritis complains of blurred vision in one eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days

 

Option C:

 

Intravenous high-dose methylprednisolone is the recommended initial treatment for visual manifestations in temporal arteritis to prevent further vision loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Continue with oral prednisone 40 mg daily: Oral prednisone is the standard treatment for temporal arteritis, but higher doses or IV steroids are needed for ocular involvement.

 

Option D. Refer urgently to ophthalmology for assessment: Ophthalmology referral is essential, but not the immediate first step

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of visual symptoms in temporal arteritis are critical to preserve vision. High-dose intravenous glucocorticoids are the mainstay of initial therapy for ocular involvement.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with new-onset headache, jaw claudication, and scalp tenderness. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is elevated. Which of the following medications is FDA approved for the treatment of giant cell arteritis (GCA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tocilizumab

 

Option C:

 

Tocilizumab, an IL-6 receptor antagonist, is specifically approved by the FDA for treating GCA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methotrexate and Option B. Rituximab are not FDA-approved for GCA.

 

Option D. Infliximab is a TNF inhibitor and is not used in GCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While glucocorticoids remain the first-line treatment for GCA, tocilizumab is an important alternative for patients who cannot tolerate glucocorticoids or who experience relapses despite glucocorticoid therapy. It is essential to be aware of the available treatment options for GCA to provide optimal care for patients.

choices.text: Doppler ultrasound of the carotid arteries

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weight loss, and claudication in her arms and legs. Physical exam reveals diminished pulses in the upper extremities and a carotid bruit. Which of the following imaging modalities is the GOLD STANDARD for confirming the diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contrast-enhanced CT angiography

 

Option C:

 

While all options can be helpful in the evaluation of Takayasu arteritis (TAK), contrast-enhanced CT angiography is considered the gold standard for visualizing the characteristic arterial wall thickening, stenosis, and aneurysms in large vessels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: Chest X-ray is not sensitive enough to detect early vascular changes.

 

Option B. Doppler ultrasound of the carotid arteries: Doppler ultrasound can assess blood flow but is limited in visualizing the arterial wall in detail.

 

Option D. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA): MRA is a good alternative to CT angiography, but CT is often more readily available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the gold standard imaging modality for TAK is essential for timely diagnosis and appropriate management. While other imaging modalities can provide supportive evidence, CT angiography remains the most definitive diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A 28-year-old Asian woman presents with fatigue, weight loss, and arm claudication. Physical exam reveals a blood pressure discrepancy between arms and diminished brachial pulses. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Takayasu arteritis

 

Option D:

 

The patient's young age, Asian ethnicity, constitutional symptoms, and vascular findings (pulse discrepancy, claudication) are classic for Takayasu arteritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Giant cell arteritis: Typically affects older individuals and involves cranial arteries.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa: Affects medium-sized arteries and presents with multisystem involvement.

 

Option C. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is a childhood vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis that predominantly affects young women, particularly those of Asian descent. It is important to consider this diagnosis in patients presenting with characteristic clinical features and to initiate prompt evaluation and treatment to prevent complications.

choices.text: Biopsy of a skin nodule

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of hepatitis B presents with fever, weight loss, and abdominal pain. He also complains of new-onset muscle weakness and skin nodules. Which of the following diagnostic tests would have the HIGHEST diagnostic yield for polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy of a skin nodule

 

Option B:

 

Biopsy of symptomatic tissues like skin nodules in PAN offers the highest diagnostic yield, revealing necrotizing vasculitis with fibrinoid necrosis and inflammatory cell infiltrates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) testing: ANCA is usually negative in PAN.

 

Option C. Abdominal ultrasound: Ultrasound might show organ ischemia, but not the underlying vasculitis.

 

Option D. Electromyography (EMG): EMG can assess muscle involvement but is not diagnostic

 

Educational Objective:

 

When suspecting PAN, a tissue biopsy of an affected organ (such as skin, nerve, or muscle) is the most reliable diagnostic test. While other tests can provide supportive evidence, biopsy provides definitive proof of vasculitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a recent diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is most likely to present with which of the following renal manifestations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal failure and hypertension

 

Option C:

 

Renal involvement occurs in 60% of PAN cases and typically manifests as renal failure and hypertension due to the vasculitic involvement of the renal arteries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nephrotic syndrome: This is characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. It's not the typical presentation of renal involvement in PAN.

 

Option B. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): While RPGN can cause renal failure, it's less common in PAN and usually associated with other vasculitides like microscopic polyangiitis or granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

 

Option D. Nephrolithiasis (Kidney Stones): Kidney stones are not directly related to the vasculitic process of PAN

 

Educational Objective:

 

PAN commonly affects the kidneys, leading to hypertension and renal failure. Recognizing this association is crucial for early diagnosis and appropriate management to prevent irreversible kidney damage.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a 5-day history of high fever, bilateral conjunctivitis, erythema of the oral mucosa and lips, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The child’s tongue is shown below. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kawasaki disease

 

Option C:

 

The combination of fever, conjunctivitis, oral mucosa changes, lymphadenopathy, and rash (erythema of the palms) is classic for Kawasaki disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scarlet fever typically presents with a sandpaper-like rash and sore throat.

 

Option B. Measles has a characteristic maculopapular rash and Koplik spots in the mouth.

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis is associated with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and atypical lymphocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the characteristic clinical features of Kawasaki disease is crucial for timely diagnosis and treatment to prevent complications, such as coronary artery aneurysms.

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation with giant cells
Transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis
Intimal proliferation and infiltration of mononuclear cells

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with Kawasaki disease is found to have coronary artery aneurysms on echocardiogram. Which of the following histopathological findings would most likely be present in the affected coronary arteries?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intimal proliferation and infiltration of mononuclear cells

 

Option C:

 

The characteristic histopathology of Kawasaki disease in coronary arteries is intimal proliferation (thickening of the innermost layer) with infiltration of mononuclear cells (lymphocytes and macrophages).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Granulomatous inflammation with giant cells: Granulomatous inflammation is seen in conditions like giant cell arteritis.

 

Option B. Transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis: Transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis is seen in polyarteritis nodosa.

 

Option D. Medial calcification and fibrosis: Medial calcification and fibrosis are more typical of atherosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the pathological changes in coronary arteries caused by Kawasaki disease is important for recognizing the potential for long-term cardiovascular complications.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a history of Kawasaki disease presents with chest pain and signs of myocardial ischemia. Echocardiogram reveals giant coronary artery aneurysms with evidence of thrombosis. Which of the following surgical interventions is MOST likely to be considered for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thromboendarterectomy and aneurysmal reconstruction

 

Option C:

 

In a child with Kawasaki disease and giant coronary aneurysms with thrombosis, thromboendarterectomy (removal of the clot) followed by aneurysmal reconstruction aims to restore coronary blood flow and prevent myocardial ischemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Coronary artery stenting: Stenting is less suitable for giant aneurysms.

 

Option B. Pericardiectomy: Pericardiectomy is the removal of the pericardium and is not relevant to coronary artery disease.

 

Option D. Cardiac transplantation: Cardiac transplantation is a last resort for severe, refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Timely surgical intervention is crucial for managing giant coronary artery aneurysms in Kawasaki disease to prevent life-threatening complications like myocardial infarction and sudden cardiac death.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with fever, rash, conjunctival injection, and swollen glands, raising suspicion for Kawasaki disease. What is the most likely initial dose of aspirin that would be prescribed by the doctor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 80-100 mg/kg/day

 

Option D:

 

High-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day) is the standard initial treatment for Kawasaki disease due to its anti-inflammatory and antipyretic effects. This high dose is necessary to manage the acute phase of the illness and reduce the risk of coronary artery complications. Once the fever subsides, the aspirin dose is typically lowered to 3-5 mg/kg/day for its antiplatelet effect.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 10 mg/kg/day: This is a low dose of aspirin and would not be sufficient for the anti-inflammatory effect needed in acute Kawasaki disease.

 

Option B. 20 mg/kg/day: This dose is also too low for the initial treatment of Kawasaki disease.

 

Option C. 50 mg/kg/day: This dose may be appropriate for some children, but the standard initial dose is generally higher.

 

Educational objective:


High-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day) is the standard initial treatment for Kawasaki disease due to its anti-inflammatory and antipyretic (fever-reducing) effects. This higher dose is crucial during the acute phase of the illness to control inflammation and potentially reduce the risk of coronary artery complications. Once the fever subsides, the aspirin dose is typically tapered down to a lower dose (3-5 mg/kg/day) for its antiplatelet effect.

choices.text: Positive cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA)
Eosinophilia on complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis and chronic cough now presents with bloody nasal discharge and a new saddle nose deformity. Which additional finding would MOST strongly support a diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA)

 

Option C:

 

c-ANCA (especially anti-PR3 antibodies) are highly specific for GPA and their presence strongly supports the diagnosis in a patient with characteristic clinical features.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Positive rheumatoid factor and Option B. Elevated antinuclear antibody (ANA) titer are not specific for GPA.

 

Option D. Eosinophilia on complete blood count (CBC): Eosinophilia is more characteristic of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the significance of c-ANCA positivity in the context of suspected GPA is crucial for early diagnosis and prompt initiation of treatment to prevent irreversible organ damage.

choices.text: It is the most common cause of mortality in untreated GPA
It typically presents with rapidly progressive renal failure
It is often associated with pulmonary hemorrhage
It can be effectively treated with immunosuppressive therapy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about renal involvement in GPA is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is often associated with pulmonary hemorrhage.

 

Option C:

 

While pulmonary hemorrhage can occur in GPA, it is less commonly associated with renal involvement compared to other manifestations like upper airway disease.

 

Explanation:

 

The other statements are true regarding renal involvement in GPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the patterns of organ involvement in GPA is important for accurate diagnosis and management. While renal involvement is a serious complication, it is not typically associated with pulmonary hemorrhage.

choices.text: Rituximab 375 mg/m2 weekly for 4 weeks
Intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days

questions.text: A patient with GPA presents with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days

 

Option D:

 

High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone is the initial treatment of choice for life-threatening manifestations of GPA like rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and alveolar hemorrhage. It provides rapid and potent anti-inflammatory effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day: Oral prednisone is too slow and less potent for this scenario.

 

Option B. Methotrexate 25 mg/week: Methotrexate is a DMARD and not appropriate for acute life-threatening disease.

 

Option C. Rituximab 375 mg/m2 weekly for 4 weeks: Rituximab is an option, but high-dose glucocorticoids are typically used first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the need for rapid intervention with high-dose glucocorticoids in patients with life-threatening manifestations of GPA is essential for optimal management and improved outcomes. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality associated with this disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and a skin biopsy revealing a necrotizing vasculitis with extravascular granulomas. Which of the following histopathological findings is most characteristic of EGPA?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granulomas with eosinophilic infiltration

 

Option C:

 

The presence of granulomas with a prominent eosinophilic infiltrate is a hallmark of EGPA. While the other options may be seen in vasculitis, they are not specific to EGPA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Leukocytoclastic vasculitis: This type of vasculitis is characterized by the fragmentation of neutrophils (leukocytoclasis) in small blood vessel walls. While it can be seen in EGPA, it is not specific and can occur in other vasculitides as well.

 

Option B. Fibrinoid necrosis without granulomas: Fibrinoid necrosis, a type of tissue damage, is often present in various vasculitides, including EGPA. However, the absence of granulomas makes this finding less specific for EGPA.

 

Option D. Lymphocytic vasculitis: This refers to vasculitis with predominantly lymphocytic infiltration. While lymphocytes may be present in EGPA lesions, the predominance of eosinophils and the presence of granulomas are more characteristic features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the unique histological pattern of granulomas with eosinophils is crucial for diagnosing EGPA. This finding, combined with clinical and serological evidence, can confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment decisions.

questions.text: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) can affect multiple organ systems. What is the approximate percentage of EGPA patients who experience mononeuritis multiplex (MM), the second most common manifestation of this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 72%

 

Option D:

 

Mononeuritis multiplex (MM) is a characteristic neurological manifestation of EGPA, occurring in up to 72% of patients. It is the second most common manifestation after pulmonary involvement. MM involves damage to two or more separate nerve areas, resulting in asymmetric sensory and motor deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the prevalence of MM in EGPA is essential for recognizing potential neurological complications and initiating appropriate management. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent irreversible nerve damage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of asthma and eosinophilia presents with new-onset shortness of breath, chest pain, and fatigue. He has recently been diagnosed with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). An echocardiogram reveals significant LV dysfunction and evidence of myocarditis. Which of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclophosphamide and prednisone

 

Option C:

 

Patients with severe or life-threatening EGPA, particularly those with cardiac involvement, require aggressive treatment with a combination of cyclophosphamide and high-dose prednisone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oral prednisone alone: Oral prednisone alone is insufficient for severe disease.

 

Option B. Methotrexate and prednisone: Methotrexate is less potent than cyclophosphamide.

 

Option D. Rituximab and prednisone: Rituximab is an option for refractory disease or in those who cannot tolerate cyclophosphamide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe EGPA, especially with cardiac involvement, requires aggressive treatment to achieve remission and prevent complications. Cyclophosphamide and prednisone are the mainstay of initial therapy, but other immunosuppressive agents like rituximab may be considered in refractory cases or when cyclophosphamide is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a purpuric rash, hematuria, and hemoptysis. Renal biopsy reveals a pauci-immune necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis. Which of the following serological markers is MOST likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA)

 

Option C:

 

p-ANCA: Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is strongly associated with positive p-ANCA, typically targeting myeloperoxidase (MPO). This finding, along with the pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis on biopsy and the clinical presentation, is highly suggestive of MPA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anti- Glomerular Basement Membrane (GBM) antibodies: These are characteristic of Goodpasture syndrome, which usually presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

Option B. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA can be positive in some vasculitides, it is not specific for MPA.

 

Option D. Anti- Proteinase 3(PR3) antibodies: These are cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) and are more specific for granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by kidney inflammation, lung involvement, skin involvement, and possible involvement of other organs.Testing p-ANCA, especially against myeloperoxidase (MPO), is a key diagnostic marker for MPA, found in about 70% of patients.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a purpuric rash on the lower extremities and buttocks, abdominal pain, and joint swelling. Which of the following diagnostic approaches would be MOST helpful in confirming a diagnosis of IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Skin biopsy with immunofluorescence

 

Option C:

 

Skin biopsy with immunofluorescence: This is the most definitive diagnostic test for IgA vasculitis. It reveals leukocytoclastic vasculitis (inflammation of small blood vessels) with predominant IgA deposition in vessel walls, along with complement C3.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing: ANA is typically negative in IgA vasculitis, and a positive result would suggest a different autoimmune condition.

 

Option B. Serum IgA levels: While IgA levels may be elevated in IgA vasculitis, they are not specific for the disease and can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Option D. Abdominal ultrasound: Abdominal ultrasound can help assess for gastrointestinal complications (e.g., intussusception) in IgA vasculitis, but it does not confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While other tests may provide supportive evidence, a skin biopsy with immunofluorescence remains the gold standard for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of Hepatitis C presents with fatigue, arthralgia, palpable purpura on the lower extremities, and peripheral neuropathy. Laboratory tests reveal elevated rheumatoid factor and low complement levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II cryoglobulinemia

 

Option B:

 

Hepatitis C is strongly linked to type II cryoglobulinemia, which is characterized by a mixture of monoclonal IgM and polyclonal IgG.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Type I cryoglobulinemia: Type I is associated with lymphoproliferative disorders.

 

Option C. Type III cryoglobulinemia: Type III is associated with autoimmune diseases.

 

Option D. Type IV cryoglobulinemia: There is no type IV cryoglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the association between Hepatitis C and type II cryoglobulinemia is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis.

choices.text: No improvement in vasculitis activity
Partial improvement with decreased cryoglobulin levels

questions.text: A patient with hepatitis C-associated cryoglobulinemic vasculitis has achieved sustained virologic response (SVR) after antiviral therapy. Which of the following is the most likely outcome regarding their vasculitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Partial improvement with decreased cryoglobulin levels

 

Option D:

 

While SVR to antiviral therapy is associated with improvement in cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, complete resolution is not always achieved. However, significant reductions in cryoglobulins and clinical improvement are expected.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. No improvement in vasculitis activity: Achieving SVR often leads to significant improvement in symptoms and reduction of cryoglobulin levels.

 

Option B. Worsening of vasculitis: While rare, there have been some cases where antiviral therapy can lead to a temporary worsening of vasculitis followed by improvement, and overall, antiviral therapy is expected to be beneficial.

 

Option C. Complete resolution of vasculitis: While SVR often leads to significant improvement in vasculitis, complete resolution may not always occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiviral therapy is essential for managing hepatitis C-associated cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. While SVR is associated with improved outcomes, patients may still require additional immunosuppressive therapy or other interventions to achieve complete remission of vasculitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with recurrent, long-lasting wheals on her trunk and limbs, accompanied by joint pain and abdominal discomfort. The lesions often leave a bruise-like mark. Laboratory tests reveal normal C3 and C4 complement levels. Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-C1q antibody

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings strongly suggest hypocomplementemic urticarial vasculitis (HUV), a variant of urticarial vasculitis characterized by low levels of complement components. While C3 and C4 levels may be normal, anti-C1q antibodies are often elevated in HUV. These antibodies are directed against the first component of the complement cascade and can activate the complement system, leading to the inflammatory response seen in urticarial vasculitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): While ANA can be positive in some cases of HUV, it is not specific and can be found in other autoimmune diseases.

 

Option B. Anti- double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibody: This antibody is more specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

 

Option D. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA): ANCA is associated with other vasculitides, like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) or microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), not urticarial vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypocomplementemic Urticarial Vasculitis (HUV):

 

  • Characterized by urticarial lesions lasting >24 hours, leaving bruise-like marks, and systemic symptoms like joint pain and abdominal discomfort.
  • Laboratory findings may show low complement levels, but normal C3 and C4 levels can occur.
  • Anti-C1q antibodies are highly associated with HUV and considered a diagnostic marker.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with recurrent painful oral and genital ulcers. He also has a history of erythema nodosum. Which of the following tests is most likely to be positive and aid in the diagnosis of Behçet syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pathergy test

 

Option A:

 

The pathergy test is a nonspecific but highly sensitive test for Behçet disease. It involves a superficial needle prick, and a positive result is the development of a papule or pustule within 24-48 hours.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA), Option C. Rheumatoid factor (RF), and Option D. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) tests are not specific for Behçet's and are more commonly associated with other autoimmune diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the utility of the pathergy test is essential in the diagnosis of Behçet disease. While it is not pathognomonic, a positive pathergy test, along with the characteristic clinical manifestations, can strongly support the diagnosis.

choices.text: HLA-B51 testing is the gold standard for diagnosing Behçet disease.
A positive HLA-B51 test confirms the diagnosis of Behçet disease.
A negative HLA-B51 test rules out the diagnosis of Behçet disease.
HLA-B51 testing can be helpful, but it's not definitive for diagnosis due to its prevalence in the general population.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man of Turkish descent presents with recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. You suspect Behçet disease. Which of the following statements regarding HLA-B*51 testing in this patient is MOST accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA-B*51 testing can be helpful, but it's not definitive for diagnosis due to its prevalence in the general population.

 

Option D:

 

HLA-B*51 and Behçet's Disease: While HLA-B*51 is more common in Behçet's disease patients (especially certain ethnicities), it's also found in healthy people. So, a positive test is suggestive but not confirmatory. Up to 50–60% of patients, depending on where they are from, can be positive for HLA B*51; however, it is not used as a diagnostic test because it is also found in up to 20% of the normal population.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. HLA-B51 testing is the gold standard for diagnosing Behçet disease and B. A positive HLA-B51 test confirms the diagnosis of Behçet disease: HLA-B*51 testing is not the gold standard for diagnosis and does not confirm the diagnosis on its own.

 

Option C. A negative HLA-B51 test rules out the diagnosis of Behçet disease: A negative HLA-B51 test does not exclude the diagnosis of Behçet disease, as some patients with the disease are HLA-B51 negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B*51 testing should be interpreted with caution and in the context of the overall clinical picture. A positive test can increase suspicion for Behçet disease, but it does not confirm or rule out the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with Behçet syndrome presents with recurrent, painful oral ulcers that have not responded to topical corticosteroids. She has no significant comorbidities. Which of the following medications is FDA-approved for the treatment of oral ulcers in Behçet syndrome and would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apremilast

 

Option C:

 

Apremilast: This oral phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitor has been specifically approved for the treatment of oral ulcers in Behçet syndrome. It has shown efficacy in reducing the number and pain of oral ulcers in clinical trials.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Colchicine: Primarily used for acute gout flares and sometimes for erythema nodosum in Behçet's, but not specifically approved for oral ulcers.

 

Option B. Azathioprine: An immunosuppressant used for various autoimmune diseases, but not the first-line treatment for oral ulcers in Behçet's.

 

Option D. Cyclophosphamide: A potent immunosuppressant used for severe manifestations of Behçet's (e.g., ocular or neurological involvement), not typically the first choice for isolated oral ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apremilast is a relatively new treatment option for managing oral ulcers in Behçet syndrome. It offers a targeted approach with a favorable safety profile compared to more traditional immunosuppressive therapies.
